Four possible gate fusion strategies for a icable gates. The individual gates on the left-hand side are combined into one fused gate on the right-hand side. The priorities among four strategies is from top to the bottom: first, one-qubit gates are fused; then two different fusion between one-qubit and two-qubit gates happen; and finally, two-qubit gates are fused together.

Logarithmic-depth decomposition of an n-controlled m-target SU(2) gate. The white diamond in k 2 is used as a conditionally clean ancilla qubit for the k 1-qubit m-target Toffoli gate. Architecture of the proposed quantum latent diffusion model. It consists of three different variational circuits: the first processes only the input latent vector; the second works on the temporally embedded sinusoidal information; the third works on both the latent vector of the image and the temporal information.

Choi State of a Quantum Comb. Here we depict the Choi state of an n=3-step quantum comb. As previously, this is constructed by swapping in half of a maximally entangled state Œ¶^+ at every open slot.

Choi States for HOQOs. Just as the Choi state of a channel can be constructed by feeding in half of a maximally entangled state, the Choi state of any HOQO can be constructed by swapping in half of a maximally entangled state Œ¶^+ at each open slot (denoted by the vertical line with an on both ends). (a) The superchannel ùíØ gets mapped to a four-partite Choi state ùñ≥ ; (b) The process matrix ùí≤ gets mapped to a four-partite Choi state ùñ∂. Throughout, we will reserve orange and yellow to depict processes with a fixed causal order (see Sec. ) and processes with indefinite causal order (see Sec. ), respectively.

Choi States for HOQOs. Just as the Choi state of a channel can be constructed by feeding in half of a maximally entangled state, the Choi state of any HOQO can be constructed by swapping in half of a maximally entangled state Œ¶^+ at each open slot (denoted by the vertical line with an on both ends). (a) The superchannel ùíØ gets mapped to a four-partite Choi state ùñ≥ ; (b) The process matrix ùí≤ gets mapped to a four-partite Choi state ùñ∂. Throughout, we will reserve orange and yellow to depict processes with a fixed causal order (see Sec. ) and processes with indefinite causal order (see Sec. ), respectively.

RB protocol in the presence of non-Markovian noise: The process matrix construction provides a natural framework to study non-Markovian effects in RB. Each noisy gate {ùíû 1, ùíû 2, ‚ãØ,ùíû m+1} can be divided into ideal Clifford gates {G 1,G 2,‚ãØ,G m+1} which act only on the system and the noise is captured by the process matrix comb (in grey).

Degree of entanglement for various bipartite states is exhibited. The QD in a bipartite state `A' and another QD in a bipartite state `B' as shown in are entangled. Four possible entanglement are reported here. (i) Both QDs in bipartite state `A', represented as A 1‚Üí A 2, (ii) Both QDs in bipartite state `B', represented as B 1‚Üí B 2, and (iii)/(iv) one QD in state `A' and the other in `B' represented by A 1‚Üí B 2 and B 1‚Üí A 2.
A quantum circuit for the quantum search algorithm used to solve the TSP.

Block properties that enable the algebraic compression of quantum circuits . Matchgates satisfy the (a) fusion, (b) commutation and (c) turnover properties. Fusion and turnover properties involve a change in the angles of the gate, while commutation does not. These properties lead to (d) algebraic compression, which states that a triangle can absorb any matchgate. The arrows show how the incoming matchgates travel through the triangle.

Young diagram representation and entanglement structure analysis of multi-body systems. (a) All possible Young diagrams for a 4-particle system; (b) The separability hierarchy of N-qubit states; (c) Characterization of the entanglement structure of a 9-body system using Young diagrams, where it can be divided into h=4 subsystems, with an entanglement depth of w=5, corresponding to the height h and width w of the Young diagram.
